body: I'd expect that behaviour, as we generally expect it to be a string or class, not an instance which I guess a symbol is. I suppose we could special case special primitives but is it worth it?

It seems to work for other instances, just not symbols:

``` ruby
obj = Object.new

describe obj do
  it { expect(subject).to eq(obj) }
end
```

Can you point to the specific code that’s causing this bug (i.e. where the special case would need to be inserted)? I’m new to the codebase and am not quite sure where this is happening.

> I'd expect that behaviour, as we generally expect it to be a string or class, not an instance which I guess a symbol is. I suppose we could special case special primitives but is it worth it?

Classes and strings are most common, but most other built-in types work.  For example, the following all work:

``` ruby
describe 3 do
  it { is_expected.to be_between(2, 4) }
end

describe 3.1 do
  it { is_expected.to be_a(Float) }
end

describe ["foo"] do
  it { is_expected.to eq ["foo"] }
end

describe (1..10) do
  it { is_expected.to be_a(Range) }
end

describe Date.today do
  it { is_expected.to be_a(Date) }
end

describe Time.now do
  it { is_expected.to be_a(Time) }
end
```

It looks like hashes don't, however:

``` ruby
describe({:foo => 3, :bar => 2}) do
  it { is_expected.to be_a(Hash) }
end
```

...fails with `expected "" to be a kind of Hash`. I suspect that may have to do with it interpretting the hash as metadata.

@sferik -- implicit `subject` is defined in [memoized_helpers.rb](https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/blob/163be38c8fc7a7bb2c9c33ffe50e60061f66f1e3/lib/rspec/core/memoized_helpers.rb#L51-L58).  That in turn uses `described_class` or `description`, which [is defined](https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/blob/163be38c8fc7a7bb2c9c33ffe50e60061f66f1e3/lib/rspec/core/example_group.rb#L42-L47) to get their values from metadata, which turns out to have a [special case for symbols](https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/blob/163be38c8fc7a7bb2c9c33ffe50e60061f66f1e3/lib/rspec/core/metadata.rb#L143-L159).

IMHO, the correct solution is to remove the `|| Symbol === candidate` special case in RSpec 3.

Perhaps it even makes sense to remove `GroupMetadataHash` altogether?
Interesting, I'd guess it's to maintain the Symbol / String parity used elsewhere. (E.g. Symbols are often used as frozen/special strings). I see no harm in removing this though...

issue.title: described_class behavior doesn't make sense when inner block is not a Class
issue.body:
Gemfile:
    gem 'rspec', '= 3.0.0'

spec/described_class_spec.rb:

```
describe Array do
  describe 'a string' do
     it { expect(described_class).to eq(Array) }
  end

  describe :a_symbol do
    it { expect(described_class).to eq(Array) }
  end

  describe Hash do
    it { expect(described_class).to eq(Hash) }
  end

  describe Hash.new do
    it { expect(described_class).to eq(Hash) }
  end
end
```

This results in two errors--one on :a_symbol and one on Hash.new.  IMO this behavior is non-intuitive.  rspec/rspec-core#1114 seems to have made an exception for when the inner describe is an instance of String, which makes sense, because `described_class.should be_a(Class)`.  However, I argue that this should be consistent for all cases where the inner describe is not a Class.  Either take its class, or skip it and move to the outer describe block, but don't return an instance.

issue.title: Tests failing with "@controller is nil" after upgrading to 3.0
issue.body:
We have the following spec:

``` ruby
describe Company::OurController do
  context :our_action do
    def valid_post_parameters(gs)
      # put gs into a known state for testing
    end

    before(:each) do
      @gs = GSObject.new
      @user = User.new
      @gs.user = @user
    end

    it 'should accept requests sent via post' do
      params = valid_post_parameters(@gs)

      post 'our_action', params

      expect(response).to be_success
      expect(response.status).to eq(200)

      #snip
    end
  end
end
```

Transpec converted it to:

``` ruby
describe Company::OurController, :type => :controller do
  context :our_action do
    # snip
    it 'should accept requests sent via post' do
      params = valid_post_parameters(@gs)

      post 'our_action', params

      expect(response).to be_success
      expect(response.status).to eq(200)

      #snip
    end
    #snip
  end
end
```

The test passed before running Transpec and upgrading RSpec. When we run this test in RSpec 3.0, we get this error:

```
Failure/Error: post 'our_action', params
RuntimeError:
  @controller is nil: make sure you set it in your test's setup method.
```

At the line:

``` ruby
post 'our_action', params
```

We are also using Capybara 2.3.0, Rails 3.2.18, Ruby 2.0.0p481, and Transpec 2.3.1. We upgraded from RSpec 2.99.1 to RSpec ~~3.0.0~~ 3.0.2.

---

I am submitting this issue in response to [the RSpec upgrade instructions on Relish](https://relishapp.com/rspec/docs/upgrade), which says:

> Run your test suite. It should still be green. If anything fails, please open a Github issue -- we consider it a bug!
